This student appears at high risk of dropout. Consider: scheduling extra one-on-one sessions, contacting guardians to build a support plan, monitoring attendance weekly, connecting them with counseling resources, and removing logistical barriers (transport, materials).

This student has moderate risk. Preventive steps: short weekly check-ins, set clear goals, celebrate small improvements, proactively address attendance or transport barriers, and involve parents early.
This student looks low risk. Keep motivation high: acknowledge progress, maintain regular parent communication, and ensure access to study materials and a predictable study routine.

Steps for attendance: call home to understand reasons, align with parents on a daily routine, offer catch-up notes, pair with a buddy for missed work, and track attendance weekly with positive reinforcement for improvements.

Academic support: diagnose topic gaps with a short quiz, plan 2–3 targeted one-on-one sessions, share structured notes, assign practice with quick feedback, and celebrate small gains to build confidence.

Parent engagement: schedule a friendly call/meeting, agree on 1–2 concrete home actions (study time, morning routine), share a weekly update, and provide helplines for transport/books assistance if needed.

Transport support: explore school/cluster transport options, arrange a peer commute group, adjust first-period expectations while stabilizing attendance, and escalate to administration for local solutions.

Well-being: refer to the school counselor, normalize asking for help, provide a calm space and check-in routine, reduce workload temporarily if needed, and connect with community mental health resources.

Financial aid: guide the family on scholarship/fee waivers, confirm eligibility documents, liaise with the headteacher for urgent cases, and ensure the student has essential materials while paperwork is processed.
Language support: provide bilingual notes/glossaries, allow answers in the comfortable language while learning new terms, buddy with a peer strong in the language, and use visuals for key concepts.
Facilities workaround: schedule labs/charging times, provide printed materials when internet is low, escalate sanitation issues to administration, and coordinate a materials kit for the student.
Engagement: use short tasks, cold/warm calling, pair-share, quick quizzes, rotate roles, and end with exit tickets to spot misconceptions early.
Exam plan: share a week-wise checklist, run 20-minute revision blocks with practice questions, give model answers, and host a doubt-clearing circle before the test.
Holiday routine: set a light daily plan (30–45 mins), give a small project, share reading lists, and schedule a check-in after the break to keep momentum.
Health support: coordinate with parents for rest and care, share missed work in manageable chunks, verify mid-day meal access, and consider workload adjustments until recovery.
Safety first: document incident, inform school authorities per policy, ensure the student has a safe contact point, monitor seating/peers, and involve parents with a clear action plan.
Mid-Day Meal: check roster and availability, report supply issues to administration, and ensure the student is not missing meals—nutrition supports attention and attendance.
Access: pair with a peer for digital tasks, provide printed alternatives, schedule school lab time, and explore community centers offering internet access.
Assignments: break tasks into smaller parts with checkpoints, add choice-based assignments, use a tracker with positive points, and call home if 2+ tasks are missed.
Watch for: 3+ absences in a month, sudden drop in marks, withdrawal in class, repeated missing work, or comments about leaving. Act early with a friendly check-in and parent call.
Referrals: school counselor, local NGOs for transport/books, health centers for wellness, and district helplines for scholarships or emergency support.

School-wide tips: track attendance trends weekly, identify transport/financial barriers early, involve parents, enable peer study groups, run mentoring circles, and coordinate support with counselors and community programs.
